meanings.definition: A temporary loss of consciousness or memory.
meanings.sent1: During the movie, the character experienced a blackout and couldn't remember what happened next.
meanings.sent2: After the accident, he had a blackout and woke up in the hospital with no memory of the crash.
meanings.sent3: When the student fell asleep during the lecture, it was like a blackout for his brain.
meanings.sent4: Her mind went into a blackout as she tried to recall the events of the previous night.
meanings.sent5: The blackout left him disoriented and confused, unable to piece together what had occurred.

meanings.definition: A period during which all lights are turned off.
meanings.sent1: During the blackout, the entire neighborhood was plunged into darkness.
meanings.sent2: The blackout lasted for hours, causing inconvenience to everyone in the building.
meanings.sent3: As a prank, they decided to organize a blackout during the surprise party.
meanings.sent4: The blackout turned the bustling city into a quiet, shadowy landscape.
meanings.sent5: The blackout created a sense of mystery and excitement as people navigated the dark streets.

meanings.definition: A suppression or censorship of information.
meanings.sent1: The government imposed a blackout on the news coverage of the protest to control the narrative.
meanings.sent2: During wartime, there was a blackout on sensitive information to protect national security.
meanings.sent3: The blackout on social media posts about the event only fueled curiosity among the public.
meanings.sent4: The blackout on the controversial article sparked a debate on freedom of speech.
meanings.sent5: The blackout on the scandalous details only increased public interest in the story.
